contents.item: [A] book is not merely a book, it is the sun as well.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: [W]e have endless opportunities to forget the self – in planting a tree for future generations; in creating a poem, a meal, a vessel of clay;
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: There's no rule in the end, but only the situation and the inclination of your mind
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: [H]ow can something cease to exist that has no solid existence in the first place?
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: The only way we can be free in each moment is to become what each moment is.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: How can a hard and fast view of a world that is never hard and fast possibly be accurate?
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: Truth is not … something to believe or disbelieve. The things we believe are always less than Truth[.]
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: [A] view of the world is nothing more than a set of beliefs, a way to freeze the world in our mind. … [T]his can never match Reality, … because the world isn't frozen.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: We can only be here. We can't leave. We are always here.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: If your idea of good opposes something else, you can be sure that [it] is not absolute or certain.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: Belief is at best an educated, informed conjecture about Reality.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: Good and bad aren't absolutes. They are beliefs, judgements, ideas based on limited knowledge as well as on the inclinations of our minds.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: And the question of Wester religion,” Flattery said, “is: What lies beyond death? But the question of the Zen master is: What lies beyond waking?
contents.owner: Frank Herbert, Destination Void

contents.item: Good times come and go. And bad times do the same.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: [E]ven in getting the wonderful things we long for, we tend to live in want of something more[.]
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: We have all sorts of stories about heaven and hell, about oblivion and nothingness, about 'coming back,' and so on. But they are all stories.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: Belief may serve as a useful stopgap measure in the absence of actual experience, but once you see … [it] becomes unnecessary.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: There's nothing you can find - … nothing you can even imagine – that doesn't originate, develop, or exist in relation to other things.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: We imagine that things come into existence, endure for a while, and then pass out of existence
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple

contents.item: To forget the self is to remember that we don't exist alone, but in relation to other people, to other creatures, to the planet, and to the universe.
contents.owner: Steve Hagen, Buddhism Plain and Simple
